conclusion: To determine how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves to the back left or right, we need to understand the relationship between the light source, the objects, and the shadows they cast.
The initial light source is positioned in front of the objects, as indicated by the shadows' positions (A, B, C, D).
Object A is a blue cylindrical object.
Object B is an egg.
Object C is a rectangular black box with what appears to be an attached fan or motor.
Object D is a white rectangular object with circular cutouts.
Shadow A is positioned behind Object A.
Shadow B is positioned behind the egg.
Shadow C is positioned behind the rectangular black box.
Shadow D is positioned behind the white rectangular object with cutouts.
The light source moves to the back left.
Shadow A will move further forward since the light source is now behind the object.
Shadow B will shift slightly to the left but mostly move further back.
Shadow C will move even further back and to the left due to the new positioning of the light source.
Shadow D will move forward and to the left, but its movement will be more pronounced than Shadow C's due to the distance from the light source.
The light source moves to the back right.
Shadow A will move further forward and to the right.
Shadow B will shift slightly to the right but mostly move further back.
Shadow C will move further back and to the right.
Shadow D will move forward and to the right, again with its movement being more pronounced than Shadow C's due to the distance from the light source.

When the light source moves to the back left, Shadow A will move forward, Shadow B will move further back and slightly to the left, Shadow C will move further back and significantly to the left, and Shadow D will move forward and to the left.
